Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Smart Morphable Surfaces for Aerodynamic Drag Control

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program award is to devise and formalize a new class of Smart Morphable Surfaces (or Smorphs), that can acquire reversible and on-demand customizable topography through a wrinkling instability. This functionality of Smorphs will be exploited for switchable and tunable aerodynamic drag reduction and control on structures with complex-shaped surfaces. This research first calls for a fundamental understanding of the mechanics of the post-buckling regime and associated geometric nonlinearities of this pattern formation process. Moreover, detailed wind tunnel testing will be performed to quantify the aerodynamic performance of Smorphs. Whereas the epicenter of the research is in structural mechanics, utilizing wrinkling morphologies for enhanced aerodynamics will require a multidisciplinary approach and open new directions in fluid-structure interaction. More broadly, the proposed research will be strongly rooted in the basis of recognizing experiments in structural mechanics as a valuable tool for discovery, supported by computational and theoretical efforts, in a vision of science-enabled engineering and engineering-motivated science.

Smart Morphable Surfaces offer the opportunity for enhanced aerodynamic performance in a variety of engineering applications, including: radomes, wind turbine towers, automobiles and aircraft structures. For all of these, devising mechanisms for drag reduction is of significant engineering relevance for better resilience of infrastructure, increased fuel efficiency, and new mechanisms for maneuverability. The underlying mechanism of Smorphs is analogous to the workings of a golf ball whose dimpled pattern reduces drag by up to a factor of two, when compared to a smooth sphere, albeit with added switchable and tunable capabilities. Close interactions with an industrial partner will provide a feasible channel to translate the fundamental research into implementable engineering applications. Concurrently to the research, novel pedagogical strategies will be explored for undergraduate laboratory-based education in engineering design and experimental mechanics. Moreover, innovative web-based tools will be developed for the online teaching of Mechanics and Materials, through indexable and browsable video-content. Partnership with the non-profit Summer Search will provide mentoring, coaching and research internships for low- income inner-city students of the Boston area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
When a thin structure is placed under compression, it can lose stability and dramatically change its shape, through a phenomenon known as buckling. In engineering, mechanical instabilities such as buckling are often regarded as a mode of structural failure. More recently, it has been recognized that the reconfigurations that arise due to buckling can be exploited for novel functional mechanisms.

The research objective of this project was to devise novel strategies for and understand the behavior of smart morphable structures that can make use of mechanical instabilities and be actuated on demand to derive function. We focused on the specific case of generating buckling-induced surface patterns that can be switched and tuned, on-demand, to control their aerodynamic drag in variable flow conditions.

The project consisted of three main thrusts.

In Thrust I, we focused on developing precision model experiments to explore and characterize the mechanics of morphable structure that can be made to excite intricate patterns on their surface. Emphasis was given to spherical and cylindrical structures. Theoretical analysis and computer simulations were performed and contrasted to the experimental results. With this knowledge at hand, we uncovered the design guidelines to target specific pattern layouts. For example, we showed that when a thin-stiff shell that is bound to a soft spherical substrate is developed under compression (e.g., through pneumatic actuation), a regular pattern of dimples akin to the dimples on a golf ball can be generated through a process that is commonly referred to as wrinkling.

In Thrust II, we studied the aerodynamic performance of the morphable structures introduced in Thrust I and tested them in a wind tunnel. We were motivated by the dimples on golf balls, which significantly reduce drag when compared to a smooth sphere. First, we focused a spherical thin-shell/soft-substrate system, which, under pneumatic actuation, develops a periodic wrinkling pattern akin to the dimples of golf balls. Secondly, we explored tubular structures comprising a rigid skeleton covered by an elastic membrane, which once depressurized develop patterns whose amplitude can be accurately controlled. The wind-tunnel tests demonstrated that the tunable nature of the specimens can be exploited to program the dependence of the aerodynamic drag on the velocity of the incoming fluid, toward targeting predefined. These findings could find applications in situations where bluff bodies are exposed to changing flow condition, for which structural resilience (e.g., in cylindrical towers) or fuel efficiency (e.g., in vehicles) are essential.

In Thurst III, we established the fundamental parallels between our morphable structures and other soft matter systems. As such, we regarded the patterns of dimples in our structures as a crystal and studied the crystallographic properties of these arrangements, focusing primarily on non-hexagonal defects. In a soccer ball, inserting 12 pentagons (defects) distributed in a hexagonal layout is necessary to produce a closed sphere. Similarly, we studied the statistics of defects in our wrinkling patterns. Our results provided quantitative evidence that this macroscopic wrinkling system can be mapped into and described within the framework of curved crystallography. These findings establish a connection between crystallography in equilibrium systems (e.g., the packing of electric charges on a curved surface) and non-equilibrium systems (e.g., the dimpled patterns resulting from wrinkling in our morphable structures.)

Given some exciting and novel, but unexpected, results that emanated from the earlier stages of this project, we extended our original scope also to include the following two investigations. Firstly, we revived the classic but long-standing problem of buckling of pressurized spherical shells and investigated the role that imperfections have on the critical buckling pressure. This problem is essential, for example, for the design of fuel tanks or to understand the working principles of microscopic drug-delivery capsules. Experiments were done with thin shells of nearly uniform thickness that were fabricated to include a precisely engineered defect, whose amplitude could be systematically varied. We studied the effect that these imperfections have on the buckling strength of our spherical shells. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first time that experimental results on the knockdown factors of imperfect spherical shells containing precisely designed geometric imperfections have been accurately predicted, through both finite element modeling and shell theory solutions. Our findings provide novel insight into the role that defects have in the buckling of structures, which is a central topic in structural engineering problems. Secondly, we studied the mechanics of elastic gridshells, which are fabricated initially flat and then made to buckle into a three-dimensional (3D) structure by compressing their extremities. The process is similar to what occurs when setting a camping tent by compression of poles that form its skeleton. In addition to experiments, we developed a theory that yielded specific design guidelines, which may be used in the future for architectural applications.
